qas.question: How do larger capacitors present their electrical characteristics?

answers.text: display the actual capacitance together with the unit (for example, 220 μF)

qas.question: What does the abbreviated electrical characteristics of smaller capacitors consist of?

answers.text: three numeric digits and a letter

qas.question: What part of the electrical characteristics of smaller capacitors do the digits of the abbreviated notation represent ?
What does the letter of the abbreviated notation for the electrical characteristics of smaller capacitors represent?
In what SI unit is the capacitance reported on smaller capacitors?
How do larger capacitors hide their electrical characteristics?

plausible_answers.text: three numeric digits and a letter

qas.question: What does the abbreviated electrical characteristics of larger capacitors consist of?
What part of the electrical characteristics of larger capacitors do the digits of the abbreviated notation represent ?
What does the letter of the abbreviated notation for the electrical characteristics of larger capacitors represent?
In what SI unit is the capacitance reported on larger capacitors?

context: Most capacitors have numbers printed on their bodies to indicate their electrical characteristics. Larger capacitors like electrolytics usually <a0_0>display the actual capacitance together with the unit (for example, <b5_0>220 μF<b5_0/>)<a0_0/>. Smaller capacitors like ceramics, however, use a shorthand consisting of <a1_0><b6_0>three numeric digits and a letter<b6_0/><a1_0/>, where <a2_0>the <b7_0>digits indicate the capacitance<b7_0/><a2_0/> <a4_0><b9_0>in pF<b9_0/><a4_0/> (calculated as XY × 10Z for digits XYZ) and <a3_0><b8_0>the letter indicates the tolerance<b8_0/><a3_0/> (J, K or M for ±5%, ±10% and ±20% respectively).
